title: The Samaritan Woman and Healing
shortSummary: John chapter 4 recounts Jesus' encounter with the Samaritan woman at Jacob's well, revealing His identity as the Messiah and teaching about true worship. The chapter also includes Jesus’ healing of a nobleman’s son, demonstrating His power and compassion. This chapter highlights Jesus breaking social barriers and offering living water that leads to eternal life.
timeline: c. AD 27-30 - Early Ministry of Jesus in Galilee and Samaria

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God who engages with the Samaritan woman, reveals His messianic identity, teaches about true worship, and performs a healing miracle.

keyCharacters.name: The Samaritan Woman
keyCharacters.description: A woman from Samaria who meets Jesus at Jacob’s well, receives His offer of living water, and becomes a witness to her community.

keyCharacters.name: The Disciples
keyCharacters.description: Followers of Jesus who observe His interaction with the Samaritan woman and learn from His teachings about spiritual nourishment and harvest.

keyCharacters.name: The Nobleman
keyCharacters.description: A royal official who seeks Jesus’ help to heal his dying son, demonstrating faith in Jesus’ word.

definitions.definition: A group descended from Israelites who intermarried with foreigners, often despised by Jews, with distinct religious practices.
A metaphor used by Jesus to describe the eternal life and spiritual satisfaction He offers, contrasted with physical water.
The promised anointed one sent by God to save His people, also called Christ.
A historic well in Samaria given to Joseph by Jacob, significant as a place of encounter and provision.

outline.heading: Jesus Travels Through Samaria
outline.description: Jesus departs Judea for Galilee and passes through Samaria, stopping at Jacob’s well, setting the stage for a significant encounter that breaks cultural barriers.

outline.heading: Jesus and the Samaritan Woman
outline.description: Jesus speaks with a Samaritan woman, offering her living water and revealing His identity as the Messiah, teaching about true worship in spirit and truth.

outline.heading: The Woman’s Testimony and the Harvest
outline.description: The woman shares her experience, leading many Samaritans to believe. Jesus teaches His disciples about the spiritual harvest and the joy of laboring in God’s work.

outline.heading: Many Samaritans Believe
outline.description: The Samaritans come to Jesus, believe in Him based on His word and their own experience, affirming Him as the Savior of the world.

outline.heading: Jesus Heals the Nobleman’s Son
outline.description: Jesus returns to Galilee and performs a healing miracle for a nobleman’s son, demonstrating His authority and prompting faith in the nobleman and his household.

application: Engage with those different from you in faith and love, following Jesus’ example of breaking cultural and social barriers.
Seek the living water Jesus offers through prayer and Bible study to satisfy your deepest spiritual thirst.
Worship God in spirit and truth, focusing on a genuine relationship with Him rather than external rituals.
Trust Jesus’ word in difficult circumstances, just as the nobleman believed Jesus’ promise of healing.

keyVerses.text: But whosoever drinketh of the water that I shall give him shall never thirst; but the water that I shall give him shall be in him a well of water springing up into everlasting life.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Jesus as the source of eternal life and spiritual satisfaction.

keyVerses.text: Jesus saith unto her, I that speak unto thee am he.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus openly declares Himself as the Messiah to the Samaritan woman, affirming His divine identity.

keyVerses.text: But the hour cometh, and now is, when the true worshippers shall worship the Father in spirit and in truth: for the Father seeketh such to worship him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the nature of true worship that God desires from His people.

keyVerses.text: Jesus saith unto him, Go thy way; thy son liveth. And the man believed the word that Jesus had spoken unto him, and he went his way.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the power of Jesus’ word and the importance of faith in His promises.
